entry.title: Re: Outbound Delivery for Return PO Allows Quantity Highe...
entry.content:
Good day @Mario_Figueirin 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following reference.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/741d645473c50d4ee10000000a423f68.html?locale=en-US

The reason for what you described is, the system only performs ATP checks if you configured it to do so. Rather, the system uses RL deliver type for returns and this does not trigger availability check.

In summary, when you work with RPO or Returns to Vendor processes in public cloud, the system may allow your outbound deliveries even if the quantities are greater that your available stock. This is because as mentioned earlier, the system does not check stock availability by default for outbound deliveries in return scenarios. You can prevent this and enforce quantity validation by enabling availability checks and possible implement a custom logic to enforce stricter validation rules.

There are a few options on how you can handle that:

First option: is to use the Manage Product Master Data app to maintain ATP check:

  • In your MRP 3 tab; ensure your availability check=2 and ensure plant-specific view is correctly maintained.
  • Then use the Configure your Solution App (SSCUI 102603), maintain checking rule (set stock types and exclude special stocks or include as you need)
  • Ensure Checking Rule is assigned. Note that adjusting checking rules directly to delivery types like RL may not be available due to its clean-core principle.

You may also consider raising an incident with SAP to enable stock check on delivery creation for returns

 

Second option: You can use a BAdI to validate quantity and raise an error or warning before deliver is created.

  • Use BADI_SD_DELIVERY_ITEM to implement your custom check (The rule could be: the system should compare requested delivery quantity against the stock available in your system; if higher, it should trigger a warning message.)

Check out this source for a list of available BAdIs and Custom Logic: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/aff0b3f5f46c42a2b2c0fabfc233bab2/78ac6e6632494a8dbc0a63c8b63f6d77.html?locale=en-US

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: üáßüá™ Build AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Gent, Belgium)
entry.content:
This SAP CodeJam event is on the topic of Build AI services using the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, SAP AI Core and Generative AI Hub. It is beneficial if you have some basic knowledge about JavaScript as we're using the SAP Cloud SDK for AI with the JavaScript variant.

This CodeJam introduces attendees to aspects of exposing generative artificial intelligence (genAI) capabilities to execute tasks using a given business context.

During this event, you'll become acquainted with the theory behind genAI, SAP AI Core, SAP AI Launchpad, and learn how to use the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model to expose AI capabilities through your own OData service.

While working through the exercises, you'll become comfortable creating CDS-based service definitions and integrating them into the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and SAP AI Core Foundation Models.

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Thursday February 26th, 2026 in Ghent, Belgiium üáßüá™ from 10:00 am - 04:00 pm. The workshop site will be the delaware offices in Ghent. The event is kindly being hosted by delaware Belgium.

The event will be held in english.

The instructor is the Developer Advocate @KRiedelsheimer .

Prerequisites: Any Chromium-based web browser, such as Google Chrome.

Please note that seating is limited - we can only accomodate 25 attendees. Register here in the Community Event using the RSVP functionality.

For more information on SAP CodeJam events, to ask questions, and to chat with your fellow attendees, head over to the SAP CodeJam group.

entry.title: Re: How MIRO to be automatically recalculated when changi...
entry.content:
Dear @Wenqingyang,

In Public Cloud there‚Äôs no configuration switch like in on-prem IMG to force this.

Enable Automatic Amount Correction in the Edit Supplier Invoice Settings app (F3813). This is the cloud-friendly equivalent of setting user parameter IVAMOUNTADJUST = X

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/762c6f8628b44a13af2dc2483dd5a163.html

 

Important. If you‚Äôre actually in the Fiori apps Create Supplier Invoice/ Manage Supplier Invoices flow (not MIRO advanced), automatic recalculation when changing quantity is not supported, so you must adjust amounts manually or use the Advanced (MIRO) app for that behawior.

More details below from SAP Community:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/amount-calculate-as-quantity-changed-in-s4-public-cloud/qaq-p/12817402

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Direct Debit Advance Notices for Mandates in Contract Accounting (S/4HANA & S/4HANA Cloud Private)
entry.content:
This blog post introduces the procedure of creating an advance notice to inform payers about future direct debit payment collection in SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. It is aim for the usage related to direct debit mandates in Contract Accounting.

If you want to know more about direct debit mandates, see the SAP Help Portal documentation Management of Direct Debit Mandate | SAP Help Portal.

If you want to know more about this topic in SAP S/4HANA Cloud public edition, see the blog post Direct Debit Advance Notices for Mandates in Contract Accounting.

What is Advance Notices?

Before the collection of the future direct debit payments, the payee can send an advance notice to inform the payer about the payment collection.

Prerequisites

Before creating direct debit advance notices, you must complete the following customizing activities:

  1. Setting up the number ranges for advance notices
  2. Activating the advance notice function
  3. Configuring the output of advance notices, including form templates, email templates and form template for correspondence

Setting up the number ranges for advance notices

This activity allows you to set up a range of numbers within which the advance notices are valid.

  1. Open the Enter Number Ranges for Direct Debit Prenotifications using the transaction FPN11.
  2. Create entries of numerical ranges between which the direct debit advance notices are valid.

Activating the Advance Notice Function

In this activity you activate the direct debit advance notice function. Complete the following activations in different steps:

  • Open the Define General Settings activity using  the transaction DDMA_CENTRALSET_FICA.
    Select the checkbox.
  • Open the Define Payment Methods using the transaction FQP1.
    In this activity you activate the direct debit advance notice for the payment method by countries/regions.
    In the Payment Methods under Required master record specification group box, select the Direct Debit Prenotification checkbox.
  • Open Company Code Details for Payment using the transaction FQP4.
    In this activity you activate the direct debit advance notice for the specific company code.
    Select your company code and double click.
    In the Specifications for SEPA Payments/Direct Debit Mandate group box, select the Direct Debit Pre-notification checkbox.

    In this activity you activate the direct debit advance notice for the payment method by countries/regions.
    In the Payment Methods under Required master record specification group box, select the Direct Debit Prenotification checkbox.

Correspondence

The standard correspondence type ‚Äú0048‚Äù is used to generate output and SAP provides pre-defined application form FIN_CA_DDM_ADVANCE_NOTICE for generating the output.

You can re-define the output in the Print Workbench: Application Form transaction (EFRM) to prepare your own application form.

If you redefine your application form, open the Define Application Forms for Correspondence activity (view V_TFK070F in the transaction SM30) to replace the SAP default application form.

You can also implement BAdI FKKCORR_EVENTS_CREATE based on your business requirements.

Procedure of Creating Direct Debit Advance Notices in Contract Accounting

If you activate advance notice for a payment method, you cannot generate payment through the Payment Run transaction (FPY1) for this payment method unless the advance notice for this payment has been created. To create an advance notice for the payment, see the following steps.

  1. Create an advance notice using the transaction FPYP.
    Fill the values in the necessary fields.

    When you schedule a run, you can see the message about direct debit pre-notification with its number is created in the job list.

  2. You can display, change, reverse, or delete the advance notices of mandates using the following transactions:
    1. Display: FPPRN3
    2. Change: FPPRN2
    3. Reverse: FPPRN8
  3. Print the correspondence using the transaction FPCOPARA.
    Fill in the fields in the Run ID and schedule program run. You can refresh the Run Status until you see the Program Run is set to Complete.
    To check the output, you can use Correspondence History transaction (CORRHIST)
    When the Advance notice is generated, you can continue and use transaction FPY1 to generate Payment.
  4. Execute a payment run with advance notices using the transaction FPY1.
    You must select the Pre-Notified Items checkbox to include the open items in payments.

    After you schedule a run, you should see a message - Payment is made in accordance with direct debit pre-notification (num.)

You can ensure that the direct debit is executed only within or after a given number of days after the direct debit advance notices.

Implement your own logic in the event 657 to set Execution Date. Then you can use the option Execution Date To on the selection screen in the Payment Run transaction (FPY1).

DATA: lv_pnexd      TYPE pnexd_kk,
      lv_ddan_calid TYPE tfacd-ident,
      lv_num_days   TYPE i.

  " Only for Advance Notice for Direct Debit Mandate
  IF i_fkkprnh-mndid IS INITIAL OR
     i_fkkprnh-anwnd NE cl_fkkid_ddm_ut=>get_anwnd_for_ddm_fica( ).
    RETURN.
  ENDIF.

  " Calculate Minimum Number of Days between Notification and Collection
  IF i_process = 'I'.

    lv_num_days    = 10. " set default value for number of days
    lv_ddan_calid  = ''. " set default calendar id

    CALL FUNCTION 'FKK_ADD_WORKINGDAY'
      EXPORTING
        i_date      = sy-datum
        i_days      = lv_num_days
        i_calendar1 = lv_ddan_calid
      IMPORTING
        e_date      = lv_pnexd.
    IF c_fkkprnh_cus-pnexd < lv_pnexd.
      c_fkkprnh_cus-pnexd = lv_pnexd.
    ENDIF.
  ELSEIF i_process = 'U'.
*   nothing to change
  ELSEIF i_process = 'R'.
*   nothing to change
  ENDIF.

 

If the standard selection criteria in the Payment Run transaction (FPY1) are not enough, you can add more rules in the event 610. With this event, you can reject a payment for processing when the Execution Date does not meet the requirements regarding of the number of days between the notification and the payment collection date. 

DATA:‚ÄØls_messa_kk‚ÄØTYPE‚ÄØmessa_kk. 
 
*‚ÄØimplementation‚ÄØ-‚ÄØDirect‚ÄØDebit‚ÄØMandates‚ÄØ-‚ÄØAdvance‚ÄØNotice 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØIF‚ÄØi_para-xprnh‚ÄØNE‚ÄØspace. 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØLOOP‚ÄØAT‚ÄØt_0610‚ÄØASSIGNING‚ÄØFIELD-SYMBOL(<fs_op>). 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØIF‚ÄØi_dpayc-erdat‚ÄØ<‚ÄØ<fs_op>-pnexd. 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ"‚ÄØdeactivate‚ÄØitem 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ<fs_op>-xaktp_0610‚ÄØ=‚ÄØabap_false. 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ"‚ÄØset‚ÄØexception:‚ÄØ‚ÄØPre-Notification‚ÄØwith‚ÄØUnsuitable‚ÄØDate 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ<fs_op>-poken_0610‚ÄØ‚ÄØ=‚ÄØ'053'. 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ"‚ÄØadd‚ÄØinfo‚ÄØmessage:‚ÄØ‚ÄØDoc.‚ÄØ&1‚ÄØamt.&2‚ÄØskipped,execution‚ÄØdate‚ÄØof‚ÄØdirect‚ÄØdebit‚ÄØadv.notice‚ÄØ&3‚ÄØis‚ÄØ&4 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØls_messa_kk-msgid‚ÄØ=‚ÄØ'ZZ...'. 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØls_messa_kk-msgno‚ÄØ=‚ÄØ'NNN'. 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØls_messa_kk-msgty‚ÄØ=‚ÄØ'I'. 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØls_messa_kk-msgv1‚ÄØ=‚ÄØ<fs_op>-opbel. 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØls_messa_kk-msgv2‚ÄØ=‚ÄØ<fs_op>-betrw‚ÄØ&&‚ÄØ'/'‚ÄØ&&‚ÄØ<fs_op>-waers. 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØls_messa_kk-msgv3‚ÄØ=‚ÄØ<fs_op>-pnnum. 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØls_messa_kk-msgv4‚ÄØ=‚ÄØ<fs_op>-pnexd+6(2)‚ÄØ&&‚ÄØ'/'‚ÄØ&& 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ<fs_op>-pnexd+4(2)‚ÄØ&&‚ÄØ'/'‚ÄØ&& 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ<fs_op>-pnexd(4). 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØAPPEND‚ÄØls_messa_kk‚ÄØTO‚ÄØt_messa_kk. 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØENDIF. 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØENDLOOP. 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØENDIF.

You can refer to the following SAP Notes:

  • 3526188 - Direct Debit Mandates in Contract Accounting #4 (Advance Notice for Direct Debit) 
  • 3526296 - Direct Debit Mandates in Contract Accounting #3 (Advance Notice for Direct Debit) 

Is this blog post helpful to you? Leave comments below to let us know your thoughts.

entry.title: Re: How to create an User Provided Service from the MTA.yaml (Cloud Foundry)?
entry.content:
Any possibilities, we can provide the values using the environment variables in the MTA file defined in the .env variable as mentioned below -

- name: sample-ups-service
  type: org.cloudfoundry.user-provided-service
  parameters:
    config:
      clientid: ${CLIENT_ID}
      clientsecret: ${CLIENT_SECRET}
      url: ${API_URL}
  properties:
    the-service-name: ${service-name}

entry.title: Getting SAP Commerce Initializr 5.5.x Running Locally ‚Äî and My Early UI Boilerplate Attempts
entry.content:
The Goal at Start

Set up SAP Commerce + Composable Storefront locally and integrate the UI Boilerplate to experiment with theming and a color-parser PoC.

In reality, the journey looked more like:

  • Commerce Initializr showing: Initializr version: unknown
  • Features reported as ‚Äúunknown‚Äù
  • discoverPackages failing
  • UI Boilerplate not integrating
  • Trying the ui-boilerplate-demo repo and hitting yarn install ‚Üí 401 Unauthorized

The Journey Afterwards

1. Why I moved to Initializr 5.5.x or above

My initial setup used an older .tar.gz version of Initializr, which resulted in errors like:

Initializr version: unknown
Task 'upgradePackages' not found
Project contains configuration for unknown feature(s): ui-boilerplate, ui-boilerplate-grid
Execution failed for task ':discoverPackages'

Some commands ran, but not in a stable or predictable way.

To resolve this,

  • Move to Initializr 5.5.x or 5.6 (5.5.0 or newer from the release)
  • Fix global configuration (package discovery & certificates)
  • Only then attempt optional features like UI Boilerplate

Installation instructions are here:
üîóhttps://pages.github.tools.sap/cx-innovation-projects/commerce-initializr/5.5.1/#/configuration/global-config

After installing, set up your local environment credentials in local.toml.

2. Package discovery on 5.5.x shows some errors ‚Äî and that‚Äôs expected

Even on 5.5.0, running:

initializr-orchestrator discoverPackages

may still show warnings or manifest-related errors. 

  • These do not impact the build
  • The task should not fail entirely
  • You can safely continue to project generation

Running:

initializr-orchestrator packages

gave clean, successful output:

Initializr version: 5.5.0
A new stable version is available: 5.5.1
### Initializr Packages ###
initializr-core (INSTALLED | LOCAL-ONLY)

This confirmed my setup was correct. Make sure to run the commands in accurate manner and double check your initializr version response in command shell. 

3. Fixing the PKIX Error (if you see it)

  • If you get a PKIX path building failed error during package discovery, just import your corporate CA into the Java truststore: 
sudo keytool -importcert -trustcacerts \
  -keystore $JAVA_HOME/lib/security/cacerts \
  -storepass changeit \
  -alias commerceca \
  -file organizationTrustedCertEntry.cer‚Äã

What I learned (and what I parked for later)

Things that now work reliably

  • Clean Initializr 5.5.x installation
  • Version correctly visible in terminal
  • local.toml for credentials
  • config.toml for global behaviour & discovery
  • Certificates imported (fixing PKIX errors)
  • discoverPackages completing with only harmless warnings
  • initializr-orchestrator packages returning valid results
  • Successful project generation:
    • projectInfo
    • installDependencies
    • generateProject
    • ./gradlew setup

‚è∏Things I parked for Part 2

  • Using UI Boilerplate via Initializr features
  • Running ui-boilerplate-demo without internal npm/Yarn registry issues

üìùFinal Note

With Initializr 5.5.x and correct local/global configurations, the setup is finally stable‚Äîgood enough to continue with Commerce + Spartacus.
Anyone can follow UI Boilerplate exploration now. 

Links related to UI BoilerPlate installation: https://pages.github.tools.sap/cx-innovation-projects/ui-boilerplate/#/uib/getting-started/installation

entry.title: Harnessing Reporting Potential, by Thinking outside of the Box ‚Äì Part 1/3 SAC Jump & Run Blog series
entry.content:
Harnessing Reporting Potential, by Thinking outside of the Box - Part 1/3 SAC Jump & Run Blog series

Solving Reporting needs in SAP Analytics Cloud by passing limitations with workaround

After years of experience within the area of SAC reporting, I cannot count how often I heard colleagues, business partners, or customers complain about SAC limitations which eventually hinder the reporting potential. Like every software, the limitations in SAC stem from focus in a certain area which will result in the underdevelopment of another area. While this statement is partly true, it has shown that almost every obstacle can be overcome by thinking outside the box. Instead of being frustrated about the straight path which is blocked, users find creative tricks and workarounds and share them with the community. To prove my point, I have created a Jump & Run demo in SAC! Although such games are not part of the tool‚Äôs scope, the implementation was still easy, if one is willing to make some compromises.

Part 1 ‚Äì the Game

Let me introduce you to my demo, which I will use to explain how I was able to use the potential of SAC to my advantage and discuss certain features which helped me to do so:

Figure 1: Overview SAC Jump & Run

The demo I have created is a playable, though not very complex, jump & run game. It allows the player to control their character (1) by using buttons (2). These buttons trigger the character to automatically run in two different directions, jump, or stay still.
Throughout the game, a moving enemy (3) creates constant tension, as it can cost the player valuable lives (4). The player is expected to use platforms in order to collect coins (5). Once all coins are collected, the level is completed by reaching the portal (6).

Figure 2: Jump & Run Gameplay

The most important features, which were not only helpful in creating this game, but also in fulfilling reporting requirements, are the following:

  • Panels
  • Scripting, especially Events & Timer
  • Images & Animations

In this blog series, I will discuss all mentioned features and explain why all of them are powerful tools for responsive reporting and, additionally, helpful when creating a jump & run game. The first blog will focus on Panels.

Part 2 - Panels & the responsive (play-)world

 Why ‚Äúeverything‚Äù should be in a panel

What are panels?

Panels are containers used to organize and group objects by placing them inside. What makes them such a powerful tool for responsive dashboards is the relative positioning and sizing of these objects. This means that objects are set in a proportional ratio to each other and the panel, which makes the whole group automatically responsive.

Dashboards are often supposed to work on various devices and screen sizes, such as conference room screens, desktops, tablets, or phones. Responsive stories in combination with nested panels are a crucial factor for achieving the desired adaptability. Hence, they should provide the whole structure of the dashboard. As mentioned before, every part can be put in relation to each other, except the highest layer of panels. They provide the overall structure and require a fixed number of columns or rows in the grid system. In responsive stories this step can be handled rather easily, as the lanes of a story can be configured based on the end-device. The SAC user interface allows to adjust how much of the grid every lane can use. Another useful feature of responsive stories is the automatic transformation of components, such as charts and filters. They will show up in their mobile form, when the dashboard is opened on a mobile device. Even outside of responsive stories, panels are a powerful tool for structuring and grouping.

Note: Although a panel‚Äôs official unit weight is 0.1 according to ‚ÄúBest Practices for Performance Optimization in Story Design‚Äù, they do not impact story performance.

How Panels were used in the Jump & Run

Before diving into the application of panels in the classic reporting sense, I will explain how they were used in the Jump & Run. Note that the game was only developed for desktop and has not yet been adapted for mobile devices.

Figure 3: Simplyfied panel structure in the SAC Jump & Run

Applying the logic described above, the whole content of the game is nested in one panel. This ‚Äúouter panel‚Äù (Panel_Game) is only used to provide structure and does not directly contain any visible elements. Within this panel are three other panels, referred to as ‚Äúinner panels‚Äù (Panel_PlayerInformation, Panel_Playfield, Panel_Ground) which provide structure for the game and include visible content. One panel represents the header, containing information about the player status and the controls. The middle panel includes the playable world in which the player can move, and one panel is used for the ground. All inner panels are responsive and adapt to changes in the outer panel.

Inside these panels are panels which are supposed to fulfil a specific task. As shown by the fields outlined in red, one panel provides images of the collected coins and remaining lives, while the other includes the control panel which allows to move the player. Similar to the other panels, these are responsive as well and only require rework when the screen size falls below a certain value. In addition, it makes rearranging specific parts, such as the controls, fairly easy. As all necessary parts are grouped within the panel, they can be rearranged with one "click" without altering the proportions.

Panels in responsive Reporting

Checking the latest updates on the phone while waiting for the next flight to catch, diving into details from the desktop, or discussing current trends with others by accessing the data on a tablet. These and many others are typical examples of use from dashboards. By using responsive stories, lanes, and panels, modern dashboards can be created which can cover these applications.

Achieving this level of responsiveness can be challenging and requires creative conceptualisation. One key component is what I call ‚ÄúTiles‚Äù in this blog. They are a specific way of using panels to structure responsive layouts. While they can differ in size, form, and nested objects, they all follow a common structure. This allows them to be replaces easily with other tiles.

Figure 4: Structure Tile               Figure 5: Example Tile (Data from BestRunJuice Sample)

The basic structure was already looked at in the paragraph above, however, I will now shed light on how to structure them for effective reporting. As known already, an invisible outer panel provides the overall positioning and sizing in the grid and lanes. The inner panel adds a visible structure, such as background colour and borders. Nested in there are panels which contain specific elements. In the example provided, I used a title/text, created an area for numeric charts, which again is split in two separate parts with their own subpanels, and left space for a big chart with visualisations. Using this approach results in a fully responsive tile which could look similar to the last figure I provided (Figure 5). It is important to note that all panel and chart positions and size properties are expressed as a percentage of their parent elements, except for the font-size of the title.

Outlook

In the next part of this blog, I will discuss the scripting behind the game, the utilization of global variables, functions, events and especially timer to make the panels and images playable.

entry.title: When Large XML Breaks SOAP in SAP CPI: Understanding CXF Limits, Misleading Errors, and the Real Fix
entry.content:
Prerequisites:

Recently we faced an issue: a large EPCIS payload caused CPI‚Äôs SOAP Adapter to crash with pretty technical error text:

Error Details
org.apache.camel.InvalidPayloadException: No body available of type: java.lang.String but has value: org.apache.camel.component.cxf.converter.CachedCxfPayload@22fcc44c of type: org.apache.camel.component.cxf.converter.CachedCxfPayload on: Message. Caused by: Error during type conversion from type: org.apache.camel.component.cxf.converter.CachedCxfPayload to the required type: java.lang.String with value org.apache.camel.component.cxf.converter.CachedCxfPayload@22fcc44c due to java.lang.IllegalStateException: Current event not START_ELEMENT or END_ELEMENT. Exchange[69E7F6624A5A223-000000000000000A]. Caused by: [org.apache.camel.TypeConversionException - Error during type conversion from type: org.apache.camel.component.cxf.converter.CachedCxfPayload to the required type: java.lang.String with value org.apache.camel.component.cxf.converter.CachedCxfPayload@22fcc44c due to java.lang.IllegalStateException: Current event not START_ELEMENT or END_ELEMENT], cause: java.lang.IllegalStateExcept...

Nothing in this exception suggests ‚Äúyour XML is too big‚Äù and the message was only 10M which is below default 40M SOAP Adapter max.

The Real Cause: Apache CXF XML Security Limits

CPI‚Äôs SOAP Adapter is built on Apache CXF and Apache Camel.
Before CPI ever sees the message, CXF enforces several safety thresholds:

Our EPCIS messages contained more than 100K child elements ‚Äî far beyond the 50,000 limit.

Once CXF hits a threshold, it stops parsing.
Camel then tries to convert an incomplete payload into a String or DOM ‚Äî and fails with a meaningless type-conversion exception.

Why You Cannot ‚ÄúFix the XML‚Äù

In many regulatory or B2B integrations, the message structure is dictated by standards.
In this case, reducing batch size or restructuring XML was not feasible:
the EPCIS payloads legitimately exceeded CXF‚Äôs defaults.

So we raised an SAP ticket.

SAP‚Äôs Proposed Solution

SAP confirmed the issue and outlined the steps needed to resolve it:

  1. Provide your CPI/Integration Suite tenant URL. SAP adjusts parameters at the tenant runtime level.
  2. Specify the new maxChildElements limit. Choose a value based on your maximal observed EPCIS batch size.
  3. Approve a maintenance window for restart. SAP must restart your tenant‚Äôs processing node to activate new CXF settings. Downtime: 15‚Äì20 minutes.

üí°Why a Tenant Restart Is Required ‚Äî Even in a CI/CD Cloud

This is a common point of confusion.

CPI feels like a CI/CD-managed cloud service, so why does SAP need a restart? Here‚Äôs the reason in simple terms:

CPI is cloud-hosted, but each tenant still runs on Java/Camel runtimes.

When SAP changes CXF parser limits, they are modifying JVM-level runtime properties that Camel and CXF read only at startup.

Just like changing JVM memory parameters, thread pools, or parser configurations:
these cannot be hot-reloaded.

So the restart isn‚Äôt a flaw ‚Äî it‚Äôs a consequence of:

  • the underlying Java processes
  • Camel routing engines
  • CXF parser initialisation

It is normal and expected behaviour

‚úîÔ∏èKey Takeaways

  • CPI SOAP Adapter errors can be misleading when XML is too large.
  • The real limits come from Apache CXF, not SAP configuration mistakes.
  • EPCIS and similar standards may exceed maxChildElements.
  • XML cannot always be made smaller ‚Äî sometimes the standard dictates structure.
  • SAP can raise limits, but must restart the tenant to apply changes.

entry.title: Data Migration Cockpit - VC Material variant
entry.content:
We are currently using the SAP Data Migration Cockpit (DMC) in S/4HANA to migrate Material Master data, including Variant Configuration (VC) for configurable materials.

We have encountered an issue when attempting to migrate Classic Variant Configuration (i.e., configurations that are not Advanced Variant Configuration - AVC).

The Technical Observation

Upon tracing the migration process, it appears the DMC migration object invokes the Function Module VCH_MATERIAL_CONFIG_CREATE. Inside this FM, we identified a hard-coded check or logic related to the processing mode:

The code seems to include a check that only permits the execution when the process mode (PROC_MODE) is set to 'A' (Advanced Configuration).

This effectively prevents the migration of any data related to Classic Variant Configuration (proc_mode = ' ') via the standard migration object, as the system seems to be designed to only allow AVC.

The Question for the Community

  1. Has anyone else experienced this specific limitation when migrating materials with Classic VC using the standard SAP DMC migration object (e.g., Product or similar)?

  2. What was your workaround or solution?

    • Did you have to customize the migration object in LTMOM?

    • Did you switch to a different loading technique (e.g., using a custom BAPI/FM that supports VCH)?

    • Is there a specific SAP Note (KBA) that addresses the use of Classic VC within the DMC?

Any insights or recommended approaches from the community would be highly appreciated!

Thanks Giuseppe!

#Variant Configuration #Data Miration Cockpit #Classic VC

entry.title: Re: Is there a way to populate a custom field for SAP21 -...
entry.content:
Dear @_JohnL_,

In Public Cloud you typically don‚Äôt enhance the OData service FDP_FFO_FI_INVOICE_SRV with a classic backend Badi the way you might on-prem. The supported way is in-app extensibility.

Option 1: Create a Custom Field + populate it with Custom Logic (Badi) + print it

    • Create your field in the relevant Business Context
    • Make sure the field is enabled for form output / form templates

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/918bca53037f408f91a2295d04ac16bc/b0bc154456584227a1664bd05d81fcb4.html

    • Populate the field in Custom Logic app
    • Implement the Badi offered for that business context. This is the supported way to derive/fill values in Public Cloud scenarios

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/5a27c5f57c3f4dffa6881ca587b22571.html

    • Add the field to the invoice form in Maintain Form Templates app
    • In the template based on data provider FDP_FFO_FI_INVOICE_SRV, add/bind the field to the layout

Option 2: If what you need is not already exposed in FDP_FFO_FI_INVOICE_SRV, SAP supports extending the form template using Data Source Extensions for this provider

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/918bca53037f408f91a2295d04ac16bc/fc1eb1eddef8476b8a6438256e73e7bc.html

Summary:

  • There is no free classic ABAP enhancement to directly manipulate FDP_FFO_FI_INVOICE_SRV in Public Cloud
  • The supported mechanisms are Custom Fields + Custom Logic (Badis) and/or Data Source Extensions for the form data provider, then Maintain Form Templates app to render it

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Powering Hybrid Integration: SAP Edge Integration Cell is Now Validated on ROSA and ARO
entry.content:
We are thrilled to announce a significant milestone in our partnership with SAP. After collaborative validation between Red Hat and SAP engineering teams, SAP Edge Integration Cell (EIC) is now officially supported on Red Hat OpenShift on AWS (ROSA) and Azure Red Hat OpenShift (ARO).

The official support for this is detailed in SAP Note 3247839 - Prerequisites for installing SAP Integration Suite Edge Integration Cell, which gives our customers the confidence to deploy a powerful SAP hybrid integration solution on our industry-leading managed OpenShift services in the public cloud.

What is SAP Edge Integration Cell?

For businesses navigating the complexities of the modern digital landscape, hybrid integration is key. SAP Edge Integration Cell, a component of the SAP Integration Suite, is a hybrid integration runtime that allows you to build, manage, and monitor APIs and execute integration scenarios within your own private landscape. This is crucial for use cases where data sensitivity and low latency are paramount, ensuring critical data remains on-premise or within your private cloud environment while still connecting seamlessly with cloud services.

Why OpenShift is the Ideal Platform for SAP EIC

Running SAP EIC on Red Hat OpenShift provides a scalable, secure, and consistent application platform, whether you are deploying on-premise or in the cloud. The solution leverages the power of the Kubernetes ecosystem, managed through OpenShift's robust, enterprise-grade features.

A key advantage is the use of the Operator Framework. For essential stateful services required by EIC, such as PostgreSQL and Redis, customers can easily deploy and manage enterprise-ready solutions like CrunchyData for PostgreSQL or Redis Enterprise directly from the Red Hat Marketplace. This simplifies Day 2 operations, automating tasks like updates, backups, and scaling, and ensuring these critical dependencies are managed to the same high standard as the OpenShift platform itself.

The Big News: Full Support on ROSA and ARO

Until now, running EIC on OpenShift was primarily focused on self-managed, on-premise deployments. With this official validation, customers can now extend their EIC deployments to the public cloud with our fully managed OpenShift offerings:

  • Red Hat OpenShift on AWS (ROSA): Run a fully managed, jointly supported OpenShift service on Amazon Web Services.
  • Azure Red Hat OpenShift (ARO): Deploy on a dedicated, jointly engineered OpenShift service on Microsoft Azure.

Below are some of the key benefits:

  • Reduced Operational Overhead: Red Hat SREs manage the underlying OpenShift platform, freeing up your IT teams to focus on deploying and managing SAP workloads.
  • Hybrid Cloud Consistency: Get the same OpenShift experience and tooling across your on-premise and cloud environments, simplifying management and workload portability.
  • Enterprise-Grade Security and Support: Benefit from the combined expertise of Red Hat, SAP, and your chosen cloud provider (AWS or Microsoft) to ensure your mission-critical integration workloads are secure, reliable, and fully supported.

Getting Started

The joint validation work ensures that deploying SAP EIC on ROSA and ARO is a smooth process. The architecture leverages foundational OpenShift capabilities for networking and storage, including OpenShift Data Foundation (ODF) for robust and flexible persistent storage.

For technical teams looking to deploy the solution, the Installation Guidance for SAP Edge Integration Cell on OpenShift provides detailed prerequisites, reference architectures, and step-by-step instructions.

We are excited to see how our customers will leverage this powerful combination of SAP's integration capabilities with the flexibility and reliability of managed Red Hat OpenShift on AWS and Azure.

To learn more, check out the official SAP Note 3247839 - Prerequisites for installing SAP Integration Suite Edge Integration Cell and talk to your Red Hat or SAP account team today!

Authors: Manjun Jiao & Joachim Kunze.

entry.title: Re: How to release the field of invoice quality in the ap...
entry.content:
Dear @Wenqingyang,

In Manage Billing Documents (F0797) the table you personalize with View Settings is a billing document header list. Quantity is an item-level attribute a billing document can have many items, even with different UoMs, so it‚Äôs not part of the header list‚Äôs data model and therefore can‚Äôt be released as a column/filter there

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/d2185b549a8c8e4ce10000000a4450e5.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/116ddcc5a4f244a1a138c4a8146f8dc9.html

What you can do instead in Public Cloud:

  • To see Quantity per document open the billing document (Display/Change) and check the Items area/table, item fields (incl. quantity) are available there
  • If you need a list/report with Quantity create an item-level report (recommended) using Custom CDS Views / Custom Analytical Queries based on billing document item sources

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/55a7cb346519450cb9e6d21c1ecd6ec1/55a5245a789845d89ea69f367c1d672c.html

  • If you truly need a Quantity column on the header list the only realistic way is to create a custom header field for example Total Quantity in base UoM and populate it via Custom Logic (Badi) during billing creation then add that custom field as a column in the app

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/30f3db567e662e7be10000000a44147b.html

Also, SAP own extensibility notes for this app indicate you can extend fields on billing document level, but not on item level which aligns with why Quantity won‚Äôt appear in View Settings

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/30f3db567e662e7be10000000a44147b.html

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: #CoE#JHNM ÂàÜÁ±ªË¥¶ÈóÆÈ¢ò
entry.content: Hi, No, scope item 5W2 cannot be deactivated in S/4HANA Public Cloud. According to SAP documentation, it is not possible to deactivate or delete any countries or scope bundles after activation . Scope item 5W2 is specifically listed among items that are only available during initial scoping and cannot be modified afterward. System Restrictions Initial Scoping Only: 5W2 is among scope items (including 5KF, 5HG, 2VA, 1GA) that can only be added during the initial scoping phase Permanent Activation: Once confirmed during the scoping milestone, scope items cannot be removed Group Ledger Decision: The Group Ledger selection must be considered carefully as it cannot be added or removed after initial scope finalization

entry.title: SAP Workzone Local Entry Point providerId failing
entry.content:
We recently started to get this error when deploying our multi-tenant app

Spoiler
Error creating service "horizon-mtx-workzone" from offering "build-workzone-standard" and plan "local-entry-point": Service broker error: Service broker portal failed with: Failed to create service. The parameter 'providerId' can contain up to 20 alphanumeric characters, dots, (,) or underscore (_). . CorrelationId: 625b027a-13a9-4373-4547-2a40e43a08f6
Process failed.

The parameter 'providerId' can contain up to 20 alphanumeric characters, dots, (,) or underscore (_). Seems like a very odd constraint given it needs to be unique and repeatable.

We notice it doesnt like "-" anymore and yet all the examples and help show dashes

parameters:
      config:
        providerId: ga-${org}-${space}

if we use it works some of the times

    parameters:
      config:
        providerId:  ${org}

 But it doesnt work for out subaccounts where there is a "-" in the org (majority) 

This seems like a bug to me as it doesnt meet backwards compatibility and also means we cant update the workzone config

 @AmberXu @SAPSupport @IrisSasson @FabianBerr @rupambhatta

entry.title: Can SAP Screen Personas Modify Search Help in ECC6 (e.g. VA01 Sold-To)?
entry.content:
Hi,

entry.title: Re: ABAP test cockpit (ATC) recommendations for governance of clean core ABAP development
entry.content:
Hi @AlexDemi ,

according to the new Clean core level concept there is no usage of an "illegal" data element. Only in case of ABAP Cloud when using the ABAP Language Version 5 then the syntax check assures that only released data elements can be used. But for standard ABAP there is no restriction concerning the usage SAP data elements. If you want to use an ATC Check that checks for released data elements you have to use the Cloud Readiness Checks. 

Regards,

Thomas.

Current Situation

Additional Context

entry.title: Configuration steps for process STO from SO with reference PR
entry.content:
Dear All,

Introduction:

We have 2 different locations, first one specific to deliver goods to customers but haven‚Äôt any stocks related to sales order line items, second location has stock and needs to transfer these goods to first location by system, then receipt stock in first location in this time stock it‚Äôs available to delivered to customer.

System process:

SO >> PR >> STO

Configurations steps:

  1. Assign PO type for Sales Organization:

SPRO --> Enterprise Structure --> Definition --> Sales and Distribution --> Define, copy, delete, check Sales organization --> Order Type.

  1. Configure item category:

Sales and Distribution --> Sales --> Sales Documents --> Sales Document Item --> Define Item Categories >>> Then enable check box Create PO automatic.

  1. Configure schedule line category:

Sales and Distribution --> Sales --> Sales Documents --> Schedule Lines --> Define Schedule Line Categories.

PO Type --> as u have

Item Category --> 0

Account Assignment Category --> D

Then enable check box for Purchase requisition with delivery scheduling.

  1. Determine Requirement Type by Item Category and MRP Type:

Item categories > MRP Type > Requirement type.

  1. Configure Scope of Availability Check:

  1. Generate new sales order type and link it with new setting.
  2. After receipt goods in second location and customer doesn‚Äôt need these goods:

Go through MIGO > Transfer posting > Other > MVT 411 E

Insert sales order no, from & destination‚Äôs plant (second plant) in this time after post, the stock moved from special stock in sales order to unrestricted.

Regards.

entry.title: üöÄ Automating Probation Workflows in SAP SuccessFactors Just Got Easier!
entry.content:
One of the most common requests I‚Äôve seen from clients working with SAP SuccessFactors Performance Management is:

üëâ ‚ÄúCan the probation form automatically move to Completed when status is Confirmed?‚Äù

üëâ ‚ÄúCan the form automatically show Extension steps only when the manager selects Extension?‚Äù

But until now, there was no direct configuration to make this happen.

üîÅ What We Did Earlier (Workarounds)

To meet client requirements, consultants relied on manual or workaround approaches:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Manually routingconfirmed cases straight to Completed while sending only Extension cases through the extension steps.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Launching separate Extension forms, either manually or via CPI integration.

These methods worked‚Ä¶ but they also came with extra admin effort, manual monitoring, and increased dependency on HR teams.

üéâ üéâ The Good News: SuccessFactors Finally Closed This Gap!

With the latest SuccessFactors release, this gap has finally been closed. We can now automate probation routing end-to-end using the newly introduced Business Rule capabilities in Performance Management.

Let‚Äôs walk through it üëá

üß© Scenario: Automating Probation Form Routing

üìã Requirement: In the Probation form,

¬∑         If the manager selects Confirmed ‚Üí the form should auto-route to Completed

¬∑         If the manager selects Extension ‚Üí the form should automatically move to the Extension Review Steps

¬∑       When ‚ÄúExtension‚Äù is selected ‚Üí a Probation Period field should appear and become mandatory

 

‚öôÔ∏è Solution Approach:

The requirement has been implemented using newly introduced Business Rules from the latest SuccessFactors release.

Add Review Steps Upon Form Routing:

This rule automatically routes the probation form based on the manager‚Äôs selection in theProbation Status field.

 

  • If the status is ‚ÄúConfirmed‚Äù, the form moves directly to Completed.
  • If the status is ‚ÄúExtension‚Äù, the form transitions to the Extension Steps ‚Äî Probation Extension ‚Äì Employee Review and Probation Extension ‚Äì Manager View.

 

Change Field Visibility, Editability, and Required Status on Forms:

This rule controls the dynamic behaviour of fields within the form.

When the manager selects ‚ÄúExtension‚Äù, the Probation Period field automatically appears and becomes mandatory, ensuring the required information is captured before submission.

‚úÖ Prerequisites

Before configuring, ensure the following:

 

  • Enable Latest Performance Management Forms and Business Rules for Performance Management
  • Configure relevant fields in Manage Templates
  • Create rules using Change Field Visibility, Editability, and Required Status
  • Assign rules to triggers: Field Change, Form Opening, and Form Saving

 

 

ü™ú Configuration Steps:

Configure the route map including the extension route steps.

For this scenario:  Probation goal setting by manager>> Probation goal view by employee>> probation 1st review by employee>>probation 1st review by manager>> Probation 2nd review by employee>> probation 2nd review by manager>> HR Review >> completed

After configuring the route map, enable the option ‚ÄúHidden Until Rule Execution‚Äù for the extension steps and save the changes.

Next, navigate to the Business Rules page and create a new rule using the ‚ÄúAdd Review Steps Upon Form Routing‚Äù scenario.

In this example, if the overall rating is marked as Extension (where rating value of 2 represents Extension), the extension steps will automatically appear in the form routing.

 

 Once the business rule is created, assign it to the template using ‚ÄúAssign Rules to Templates‚Äù under Assign Rules in Talent.

 

Create a second rule to control the Probation Extension Period Comments field for case where the probation status is set to Extension.

Configure the business rule as follows:

 

 

 
After completing the business rule configuration and assignment,launch the probation performance form. the extension steps will be hidden by default (as shown below).

 

 

When the manager provides the rating as confirmed, there is no mandatory comments or additional steps.

 

When the manager selects the rating as ‚ÄúExtension‚Äù, a mandatory comments box will appear as defined by the business rule.

 

Also, when the manager moves the form to the next step by selecting ‚ÄúExtension‚Äù as the input, the confirmation message shown below will appear. After that, the extension stepswill e added to the route map as per the business rule.

 

With these new Business Rule scenarios in SAP SuccessFactors, automating the probation confirmation and extension process has become seamless and efficient.

Hope this blog helps you configure and try out these new Business Rule scenarios in your instance! Would love to hear how you‚Äôre using them or what other creative use cases you‚Äôve explored. üëá

#SAPSuccessFactors #PMGM #PerformanceManagement #HXM #SAP #2H2025Release #BusinessRules #HRTech #DigitalH

entry.title: How to verify the Swiss E-ID on the SAP Business Technology Platform
entry.content:
How to verify the Swiss E-ID on the SAP Business Technology Platform

Switzerland is progressing with its new state-operated E-ID, branded swiyu, built on decentralization, privacy-by-design, and open standards. This new solution ensures the privacy design with a system where identity data stays on the user‚Äôs device, verification happens peer-to-peer, and the entire infrastructure is publicly governed.
While the official release of the Swiss E-ID is scheduled for summer 2026, the E-ID excites many customers, being the hot topic not only for the public sector in Switzerland but also E-Commerce shops for age checks and customers regulated by the ‚ÄúKnow Your Customer‚Äù guidelines.

Business Relevance

In recruiting, the identity of a new hire is a key information not only in regulated industries. Some products may only be sold to customers of a certain age or to customers which are identified. Some processes ‚Äúdigitize‚Äù the physical ID-Card or Passport using Video, other processes depend on the holder of the ID to show it physically to an agent. As all that is in an ID is data, finding better ways of handling this data should be easy?
However, having a trusted form of identification in the digital era is not as straightforward as one might think. Today, many companies are forced to use external identity validation services including video calls for a Face-to-Face verification. Those services come with high costs and disrupt the smooth user experience for the end consumer.
A trusted digital identification would solve those challenges which the E-ID aims to become. With swiyu, Swiss organizations and citizens will have a compelling solution in their hands ‚Äì ready for integration in their existing processes. SAP Switzerland wants to help its customers in this process for a simple and seamless integration.

Architecture

For the E-ID verification 3 main components are necessary: the E-ID of the consumer, the webpage where the verification process is presented and the verifier ensuring the authenticity, validity, and trust. The E-ID is stored in the digital wallet (swiyu app) on the personal smartphone of the end user. The generic verifier, an open-source application provided by the swiss government, is hosted by the company initiating the verification process. It ensures the trusted communication with the public government registry using anonymized records of the issued IDs.

What is needed for an implementation?

Knowing how the E-ID verification works in theory is nice but of little use if not used in practice. To have a verification with the E-ID in place the generic verifier application needs to be hosted and publicly accessible. The docker image provided by the government can be used to have it up and running in no time. The company running this verifier then needs to put its trust anker in the government registry to be recognized as a valid verifier. Then the webpage needs to integrate to the generic verifier. This integration allows the generation the QR Code and (once the consumer approved the validation request) receiving the results from the E-ID login.

The steps on how to perform this on SAP Business Technology Platform are outlined below.

Setting Up Your Own Verifier on SAP BTP

Setting up the Generic swiyu Verifier on SAP BTP is straightforward: it involves a registration on the e-portal of the Federal Office of Information Technology, Systems and Telecommunication (FOITT), generating a Decentralized Identifier (DID), and deploying to SAP BTP.

Prerequisites:

  • Cloud foundry space
  • PostgreSQL Entitlement

Register on the swiyu Base & Trust Registry

Before starting the technical setup, you register on the swiyu Base & Trust

  1. Register your business or yourself on the e-portal and save the Business Partner ID for later.
  2. Navigate to the API Self-Service Portal:
    1. In the Applications tab, create a new application.
    2. After creation, select the application and subscribe to the Identifier and Status APIs.
    3. Save the Access Token, Refresh Token, and other credentials for later use.

Create a DID and Identifier Space

  1. Using your Business Partner ID and Access Token, request a DID space on the Identifier Registry. Save the Identifier Registry URL and ID for the next steps.
  2. Clone the swiyu DID Toolbox from GitHub and run it with your Identifier Registry URL to create a new DID.
  3. Save the output. The returned array contains your DID and other verification/authentication details.
  4. Store the entire output as a string in the created Identifier Space using the obtained details.

Optional: To become a trusted participant (i.e., to display the ‚Äúverified‚Äù badge when verifying credentials), register for the Trust Registry. Details can be found on the organizations page in the e-portal.

Deploy the Verifier to SAP BTP

  1. In the BTP Cockpit, start a dedicated PostgreSQL instance. The smallest tier is sufficient as the DB only holds cache data.
  2. After provisioning, create a service key to obtain authentication details for the verifier service.
  3. On your local machine, create a manifest.yml file specifying the name, instance, memory, and environment variables (see documentation).
    • When deploying only with the Docker file, you must host your verifier metadata file separately to allow the service to access it.
  4. Push the application using the Cloud Foundry CLI.

You have now deployed the Generic Verifier to SAP BTP and created an API service for verifying VCs on the swiyu Trust Infrastructure. 

 

Basic architecture of swiyu verifier integrated into SAP BTP

 

 

Accessing and Securing the API

Access your APIs via the built-in Swagger UI at: <your-server-url>/swagger-ui.html
Optionally, secure the management API endpoints using a fixed asymmetric key or an OAuth2.0 Server.
Note: This process is intended for PoC and familiarization purposes. For full production deployment, check out the deployment considerations here.

Optional: Frontend Integration
In our PoC, we also created a frontend service using UI5 and CAP to integrate JWT authentication with the Verifier Service. This makes it easier for users to interact with and test the service.

Verifying credentials

Screenshot of Credential-Check on the swiyu AppThe process of verifying credentials from a wallet begins when the wallet user scans an offer QR code. This QR code must contain a (deep-)link, which you generate through an API call to the management API of your verifier service.
After scanning the QR code, the wallet holder is prompted to either accept or decline the verification request (see figure 1). If the user accepts, the requested details are sent to the verifier service. These verification results can then be retrieved either by polling the service or by receiving them through a webhook callback.

 

 

Conclusion

You have now deployed and configured the generic swiyu verifier on SAP BTP, registered on the swiyu trust registry, created a DID/identifier space, and enabled QR-based credential verification (with an optional UI5/CAP frontend and basic security options).
Based on this, integration in business processes can replace costly external identity checks by enabling seamless, privacy-preserving E-ID verification for recruiting, age checks, KYC flows and other customer-facing processes while keeping identity data on the user‚Äôs device and relying on the public trust registry.

In a next step, we will explore how to issue certificates, including creating verifiable credentials, the issuer workflow, required registry entries and production-grade deployment. Stay tuned!

Special Thanks goes to Matthias Beeler for developing the PoC and helping create this Blog post, but also Alex Finger, Michael Kaczalak and Patric Imark for driving the topic!

 

Sources:
https://swiyu-admin-ch.github.io
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Know_your_customer

entry.title: VSR select the wrong lane - carrier selection should falls back to change the respective lane / MTR
entry.content:
We want to run the VSR optimizer to select the lane with the appropriate mode of transport that matches the same lead time (calculated as the difference between the loading date and the delivery date). After that, the optimizer should select the carrier with the lowest cost based on the charge management data (calculation sheet/rate table).

However, we are facing several issues:

  1. The system is not selecting the correct lane that matches the required lead time.
  2. The lowest-cost carrier is not being chosen.
  3. After selecting the carrier, the lane (representing the mode of transport) should be updated in the freight order creation.

We are currently using ‚Äúmeans of transport‚Äù and ‚Äúresource‚Äù to represent the mode and service (e.g., Air Express, Road Economy, Air Economy). How can we achieve this?

entry.title: Re: MRP run is not working (MD02) min/max
entry.content: Hi Dennis, HB ignores how much has been consumed: it does not perform consumption-based planning, but instead relies solely on the current available stock level in relation to the defined maximum stock level. When available stock falls below the reorder point, the system will always plan a replenishment quantity to bring stock back up to the maximum level, regardless of how much is missing compared to the reorder point or the safety stock.

entry.title: How to Retrieve Approvers for a Custom BO Approval Process (Reporting + PDF Output)?
entry.content:
We are using the standard Approval Process for a Custom Business Object in SAP Cloud for Customer, and we need to retrieve approver information (current approver and full approval chain) for analytics/KPIs and for Outputs (PDF Summary). Standard data sources and SDK functions work only for standard objects, so we cannot access any approval-task details for our custom BO. Has anyone managed to extract this information?

There is plenty of documentation and examples on how to configure an approval process for a custom BO ‚Äî step definitions, conditions, screens, etc. However, once the approval process is activated, we immediately face two major functional gaps:

1) Reporting / Analytics 

We need to display who is the current approver of a custom document.
Normally, for standard objects, this can be done by joining with the data source ‚ÄúApproval Task Details‚Äù (BTMAPPV01). But SAP Support confirmed in our case that this data source contains approval tasks only for standard BOs. So there is no standard reporting option for custom objects, and we need some SDK-based solution ‚Äî but we cannot find any.

2) Approvers for PDF Form

We also need the full approval chain or at least the current approver to show it on the PDF form of the custom document.
Unfortunately, SDK methods that work with standard objects do not work here. For example, GetCurrentStepApproval.Info() on a custom BO results in a system dump (HTTP 500).

Has anyone implemented a requirement where approver details must be retrieved for a custom Business Object? How did you access approval-task or approver information ‚Äî via SDK, a custom service, or another supported method?

Any experience or suggestions would be extremely helpful. Thanks!

entry.title: Re: Production Order Printout Settings
entry.content:
Hi Mahyl,

maybe there is a problem with the sequence if you print direct after saviing. 
During production order creation (CO01) SAP processes the steps in this sequence:

The order header and operations are saved first.
Output (printing) is triggered immediately after the save.
BOM components are calculated and written to the database only afterward.

We print after release and in this moment there are all data present. 
Change output determination so that printing is triggered not during CO01 save, but at Release .

Regards 
Jarda

entry.title: Perform Asset Posting with SAP PaPM
entry.content:
Dear community,

I am working on a SAP Profitability and Performance Management model which generates as output lines to be posted as asset postings (document type
My idea was to use the remote function adapter with the standard Finance General Ledger Items function using the BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST BAPI, but I am struggling to set it right, even by passing additional attributes by mean of the extension2 values.

The test that I set up has to produce one document, with type AA, having two distinct line items: one with account type 'A' (asset) and one with account type 'S' (G/L account).

This is how I am filling the header and GL areas:

Header
Document Type: AA
Posting Date: 04.12.2025
Document Date: 04.12.2025
Company Code: XXXX (one company code defined in the system)
User Name: my username

Line Item 1 (the one to be the document type A)
WBS: a valid wbs element ID
Transaction type: 145
Asset Number: a valid asset number (with zero left padding)
Asset subnumber: 0000
Asset Transaction Type: 100
Account Type: A
Tax Code: a valid tax code
Currency: EUR
Amount: 1000

Line Item 2 (the one to be the document type S)
WBS: a valid wbs element ID (same as line item 1)
GL Account: a valid GL account
Account Type: S
Tax Code: a valid tax code (same as line item 1)
Currency: EUR
Amount: -1000


The values highlighted with purple color are those sent to the BAPI via the extension2 values. When I run the function I get the error: "Required field G/L account was not transferred in parameter ACCOUNTGL". The error refers to the line item 1, but the asset posting should not require a GL account on the account type 'A' as it should be automatically derived.
However, to try overcoming this error I saw online that some people using the same bapi, directly from abap, are filling the G/L account parameter with the asset number itself. I tried doing the same but then the following error comes out: "G/L account <asset number> is not defined in chart of account XYZ".

With a developer we also tried hard coding the posting keys to 70 (debit asset) for line item 1 and 50 (credit entry) for the line item 2, but it didn't change the outcome.

Did anyone also faced the same issue before, or has any experience with asset posting through BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST that could help overcoming this block?

I am available to provide any further detail.

Thank you in advance and best regards,
Francesco

entry.title: Posting date being updated to today‚Äôs date when uploading and approving journal entries
entry.content:
Hi experts,

SAP updates the posting date in the journal entry to today‚Äôs date when uploading journal entries using ‚ÄòVerify General Journal Entries‚Äô (F2547A) followed by ‚ÄòVerify Journal Entries in General Ledger - For Processor (Inbox)‚Äô (F2728).

Does anyone have a solution for how to prevent this from happening? This issue has only occurred since upgrading to SAP S/4HANA 2023. Are others experiencing the same problem?

Steps to reproduce:

  1. We upload journal entries using the Upload button in the ‚ÄòVerify General Journal Entries - For Requester' app (Fiori App ID F2547A). In our example, we can see the wanted Posting Date, e.g., 01.12.2025.
  2. Then, the approver approves the journal entry in the ‚ÄòVerify Journal Entries in General Ledger - For Processor (Inbox)‚Äô app (Fiori App ID F2728). SAP posts the journal entry but also incorrectly updates the posting date to today‚Äôs date.
